course.description: This course is to provide students with an awareness of the overall legal framework in which businesses in Hong Kong operate so as to enable them to apply the relevant laws and practices to business problems and practical solutions. The main objective is to give students an understanding of how the society and business function in different socio-legal contexts like the legal system and process and its influence on citizens‚Äô social rights and duties; the enforcement and honoring of agreement between private citizens, the use of business organizations in commercial society, the relationship between employee and employer from social and legal perspectives, the growing importance of business ethics and corporate social responsibilities etc.

Make sure you write as much as possible in the exams to get the marks. Even if some of the issues in the questions do not have a role in the final decision, you're still required to fully explain them.

Charles likes to test concepts that are only discussed in class but not mentioned in his lecture notes, so make sure you attend his classes and jot down everything he mentions. Pay extra attention to those topics during your revision.

reviews.comment_workload:
A double-sized A4 (either written or printed) cheat-sheet is allowed in the exams. This reduces the workload quite a bit.

The legal paper is still far too demanding to us. It's a 4000-to-4500-word essay finished by groups of 5. We're required to conduct legal research in depth from authoritative sources (Wikipedia and Google are not acceptable), critically analyze the pros and cons of the current law/political system, point out existing defects in the laws, conduct comparative studies with overseas examples, and come up with viable solutions to resolve the current issues/improve the legal system.

Our group was assigned a topic that required us to assess in the current electoral system in Hong Kong and analyze whether it conforms to democratic principles. Damn it - it's a super hard topic. I think it's more like politics than law. I wonder if we had the ability to come up with such great solutions, would we still need to sit in lectures and get tortured by all those sh!t grades? We could have been the Chief Executive then.

Make sure you get responsible and CAPABLE group-mates to do the work, or you'll end up with spending days revising all the group work in frustration.

reviews.comment_teaching:
Charles was a great instructor. He explained the concepts with lots of funny examples and did a lot of case studies with us to let us understand how to apply concepts in real-life. There were lots of notes to jot for every of his lecture, so try not to miss any. And actually, you won't wanna miss Charles' lectures coz they are actually quite interesting.

Unfortunately, he got a stroke at early Apr and was hospitalized, so the TA, KK Lee, became the emergent substitute instructor for the rest of the semester. The TA was just basically reading out the powerpoint for every lesson so I didn't pay much attention and skipped some lectures.

That's why I gave an overall B in teaching coz Charles deserved more than an A and KK Lee is a D.

Update:
Sadly, Charles passed away at 15 May due to the severe stroke he suffered at early April. Rest in peace. We will all remember your teaching and the knowledge and laughter we had in class will forever be in our hearts.
reviews.comment_grading:
10% Class participation
20% Group project
35% Midterm
35% Final

Dunno how will the class participation be graded. Maybe it's from KK Lee's impression on us during lectures (?) Do bear in mind that if you asked questions during the group project presentations, he'll mark your name down and you may score higher in participation.

For the group project, every group will be randomly assigned a topic from a list created by Charles beforehand. Originally, Charles required us to have a 4000-word limit and with footnotes and 1.5-line spacing. But after KK Lee took over, he said that there was no word limit and we can do whatever format we like provided that it's clear. Each group will also need to present their findings in class. Originally, KK Lee set the time limit to 10 mins as the syllabus does, but then he cancelled the time limit. What happened then is that some groups presented for over 20 mins and some groups need to delay their presentation to the next lessons as a result, so he kind of set a limit again for around 15 mins. The arrangement was messy.

Midterm was still under Charles' reign. There were two short questions and two case study questions, covering the first two chapters. An A4 double-sided cheatsheet is allowed.

Final was under KK Lee's reign. He conducted a survey in class and decided to have an open book open notes exam. There will be MCs and short questions on Contract Law, contents from the guest lecture on professional ethics, legal systems around the world, Tort Law and Employment Law, and case study questions for only the latter two topics.
reviews.comment_workload:
The group project constitutes the most workload. You'll need to do lots of research and dig into the current laws as well as reading lots of news related to your topic in order to find loopholes in the law and make legal recommendations to it. However, it was quite fun as you got to know much more about what Hong Kong (or China or common law states like UK and US) is currently going on. Since I have an interest in law and politics, I actually quite like doing the project. But for others, well... good luck.

For the midterm, I had gone through the powerpoints, Charles' supplementary notes and notes from his lectures for more than once in order to find useful information to be written on the cheatsheet. It was hard work.

For the final, it's open book open notes, so everyone can just print out all the slides and notes and bring them alongside the textbook (which is optional) into the exam venue. You don't need to memorize a lot of stuff but as it's open nearly everything... it's going to be tough I think.

reviews.comment_content:
The topics are incredibly interesting if you'd like to understand a bit of the basics of business law. The course covers the fundamentals of each topic (Basic concepts of law, the legal system in HK/China, contract law, employment law, tort law and business ethics).

You don't need to be afraid of the course code - trust me. I chose this course last semester because there was really nothing else to take. I thought it'd be awful but it turned out to be the best course choice by far.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Charles is super friendly and likes to make lots of jokes (though no one laughs). He uses powerpoints and a ton of word documents that contain 'past paper questions'. A typical class consists of him going through the powerpoints and then applies the concepts you just learned in the questions. You can feel free to interrupt him at any point in time to ask questions - he's always happy to clarify.

Attendance is not compulsory even though there are 'participation points'. BUT if you want to do well (which I presume you do), you NEED TO GO TO CLASS. Charles' PPT & notes (which he uploads to LMES) are not comprehensive enough. He often adds additional information. If you're a fan of taking a lot of notes and then exactly regurgitating everything the professor says then this is the class for you, seriously.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading is pretty fair to be honest.
Mid term 35%
Final 35%
Participation 10%
Group Project 20%

The group project is the really long essay you write (with other people) on a law topic. You draw this topic out of a hat with the TA. You can then go to Charles and arrange a meeting and pretend you are honestly very confused and hopeless. He will then tell you exactly what he wants in the essay - no joke. He's the nicest person on earth.

The 10% participation is a mixture of your questions in class and the verbal presentation you give with your group mates for the group project. Throughout the entire semester I think I asked about two questions... so honestly it doesn't really matter. I've been told that so long as you give the presentation, you get the full 10%.

The final exam was a mind blower because half of the paper was on Confucius. We learned business ethics in the last two weeks of the semester and Charles so happened to focus on business ethics for the final. A lot of people thought memorizing business ethics was a waste of their time and didn't revise for it... so... oops?

I got 41/50 for the midterm - slightly above mean. He never told us what we got for the group project or final or for participation. I ended up getting an A+.
reviews.comment_workload:
I took this course as a terrified Freshman. The course was not as terrifying as what everyone described it to be.
